Graphical abstract In this paper, the fabrication of a highly efficient magnetically separable organic–inorganic hybrid nanocatalyst has been reported by covalently immobilizing the copper(II) acetylacetonate complex over amine functionalized silica@magnetite nanoparticles. The prepared nanocatalyst was characterized by electron microscopy techniques (SEM and TEM with EDS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), vibrational sampling magnetometer (VSM), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) techniques. The catalytic performance of the resulting nano-composites was examined for the degradation of various organic nitro-analogues in aqueous medium at room temperature using sodium-borohydride as the source of hydrogen. This nano-catalytic system selectively reduces the nitro group even in presence of other sensitive functional groups. To achieve the best catalytic efficacy, various parameters such as catalyst loading, reaction time, effect of various bases and solvents etc. were optimized. The reaction kinetics for the reduction of o-nitroaniline to benzenediamine was studied by UV–vis spectroscopy, and its apparent rate constant was determined and compared with different copper nanocatalysts. The identification of organic residues and purity of the obtained products was analysed by GC–MS. The acquisition of this nanocatalyst has been demonstrated by employing the catalyst in hot filtration and reusability test, and the results obtained from the tests show negligible metal leaching. The nano-catalytic system can be efficiently recovered using simple magnet and reused for multiple cycles without appreciable loss in its catalytic activity. In addition, the stability of the recycled catalyst has been proved by SEM and VSM techniques. It is noteworthy that the key-features like mild reaction conditions, simple work-up procedure, high turnover frequency (TOF), no use of toxic organic solvents, ease in recovery and reusability of the catalyst makes the present protocol more fascinating from an environmental and economic point of view. Keywords Silica Magnetic nanoparticles Copper(II) acetylacetonate Nitroarenes Recycle 1 Introduction The development and growth of nanotechnology has caused a continuous shift in every aspect of modern science. So far, it has changed the perspective of the scientific community towards catalysis and brought remarkable transformations in the synthetic chemical processes. Magnetically responsive nano-materials nowadays have received immense scientific and technological interest because of their unique physical and chemical properties which endow them as an ultimate choice in the field of catalysis [1–3]. Magnetic actuation offers unique features such as eco-friendly nature, ease of recyclability and simple operation of the catalyst [2–5]. Besides, these nanometric systems also offer dynamic surface-to-volume ratio, by which, the contact between reactants and catalyst enhances dramatically. This in turn, raises the overall activity of the catalyst for desired transformation. However, their immense surface energies sometimes show a strong inclination for aggregation, decomposition and oxidation, which generally results in loss of magnetism and dispersibility. Therefore, designing of effective surface protection strategies to preserve the original characteristic of iron oxide nanoparticles is essential. Encapsulation of magnetic nanoparticles with silica is the most acceptable and promising shell forming material [6–10]. It prevents the aggregation and decomposition of magnetic cores by screening the magnetic dipolar attraction among the nanoparticles. Besides, silenous coat over iron nano-core imparts various desirable properties, such as thermal stability, chemical inertness, high mechanical tolerance and ease of functionalization. In fact, the immobilization of the metal-complex over silica based magnetically responsive nano-materials has been regarded as the most suitable catalytic system for different organic transformations, due to the numerous merits such as robustness, high chemical stability and enhanced active catalytic sites [8–11]. This integration can be seen as a green sustainable approach in catalysis, since it offers the advantages like less consumption of auxiliary substances, energy and time used in achieving separations, and hence can result in significant economic and environmental benefits [6–13]. Despite the spectacular success in the field of organic synthesis, there is always much scope available for the improvement at several levels. Recently, considerable emphasis has been given on the “catalytic hydrogenation of nitro-arenes” [14–17]. The catalytic reduction of aromatic nitro compounds to its corresponding amines is considered as an imperative and lucrative synthesis, due to its massive commercial applications in pharmaceuticals, agricultural chemicals, dye stuff, additives, polymers, herbicides and other fine chemical industries [18]. Till date, several catalytic methods have been reported for the present reaction, but these methodologies suffer from numerous limitations. In fact, the famous traditional synthesis route, i.e. Bechamp reaction was abandoned due to the emission of toxic waste and lower selectivity towards the target product [19]. Though, various catalytic hydrogenation protocols have been developed so far using different Ru, Pd, Pt, Bi, Pt/Ni, Pt/Pd and V catalysts [20–26]. But, they have increased the overall expenditure due to their limited availability and high cost. This has led the researchers to search for more economical and environmentally acceptable alternatives. Pradhan et al. reported the first catalytic reduction of several nitro compounds using Au, Ag and Cu coinage metals [27]. Hanaya et al. reported copper(II) acetylacetonate as highly selective homogeneous catalyst for the reduction of nitro compounds, as Cu is abundant, inexpensive and readily available in comparison to the earlier reported precious metals [28]. Various other researchers have also used copper based catalysts but, due to their homogenous nature [29–31], these approaches face serious problems in separation. Therefore, they are considered as the major contributors for waste generation in the chemical processes. Hence, there is a critical need to develop a simple, efficient, inexpensive and recoverable catalyst, with low or null toxicity in terms of green chemistry perspective. In continuation of our previous efforts for the development of greener catalytic protocols for various synthetic transformations [32–41], and herein, we report the fabrication, characterization and application of magnetically separable Silica@Fe3O4 based heterogeneous copper nanocatalyst for the reduction of aromatic nitro compounds at room temperature in aqueous medium. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report, where copper(II) acetylacetonate complex, synthesized via green method, has been immobilized over silica@Fe3O4 core–shell nano-support to provide an advanced, economical and environmentally sustainable nanocatalyst for the reduction of nitroarenes. The present protocol is highly potent to address the industrial prerequisites and environmental concerns. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents 3-Aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) and tetraethoxyorthosilicate (TEOS) were purchased from Fluka and Sigma Aldrich, respectively. Acetyl acetone and copper acetate were procured from Sisco Research Laboratory. Anhydrous methylene chloride, toluene, N,N-dimethylformamide and methanol were obtained from Thomas baker. The double deionized water was utilized throughout the studies. 2.2 Characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra were obtained using a Bruker, D8 Advance (Karlsruhe, Bundesland, Germany) diffractometer equipped with Cu/Kα radiation at a scanning rate of 4°min−1 in the 2θ range of 10–80° (λ =0.15405nm, 40kV, 40mA). The morphology and size of the particles were analysed by conventional and high resolution electron microscopy (HR-TEM) using a TECNAI F20 microscope (operating at 300kV with a point-to-point resolution of 0.24nm). All sampling for size and morphology observation was done by dipping carbon coated copper grid into sample suspension, subsequently putting them on filter paper to remove excessive solution from the grid, and taking electron micrographs of the particles retained on the film. The histograms of the nanoparticles size distribution, assuming spherical shape, were obtained from the measurement of about 150 particles and were reproduced in different regions of the Cu grid, found in an arbitrarily chosen area of enlarged micrographs. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis was performed using an adjacent Oxford INCA system. The metal content was calculated from the EDS results and the average values are based on 3–5 measurements on chosen spots of the analysed samples after exclusion of extraordinary high or low values (not exceeding a two-fold amount). Size and morphology analysis of prepared nanocomposites were also performed using Gemini Ultra 55 (Zeiss) scanning electron microscope (SEM). Samples were prepared by first applying double-sided tape to metal stubs. The sample was then placed onto the tape. Excess sample was removed using pressurized air. The sample was then sputter-coated with a 10nm gold layer using a Cressington-208 HR Sputter Coater. A Tekmar Sonic Disruptor model TM300 (sonicator) fitted with a microtip was used to disrupt nanoparticle aggregates in the magnetite–ethanol dispersions. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) (EV-9, Microsense, ADE) in the magnetic field range of −20,000Oe to 20,000Oe at room temperature. Digestion for the quantitative assaying of copper metal via AAS in the catalyst was performed in Anton Paar multiwave 3000 microwave reaction system equipped with temperature and pressure sensor. The UV–vis spectra were recorded using Double beam UV–vis spectrophotometer of UV 5704M Electronics Corporation of India Limited. The derived products were analyzed and confirmed by using Agilent gas chromatography (6850 GC) with a HP-5MS 5% phenyl methyl siloxane capillary column (30.0m×0.25mm×0.25mm) and a quadrupole mass filter equipped 5975 mass selective detector (MSD) using helium as carrier gas. The carrier gas was helium (rate 1.0mLmin−1) and the temperature of the injection port was 250°C. The temperature programme of the column was set to an initial oven temperature of 60°C and was increased at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 to 250°C, and the oven was held at 250°C for 5min. 2.3 Synthesis of Cu(II)-acetylacetonate complex grafted silica coated magnetite supported nanocatalyst 2.3.1 Amine-functionalized silica coated magnetite supported nanocomposite (Am–Si–Fe3O4) For the synthesis of the magnetite nanoparticles (Fe3O4), an adaptation of co-precipitation method was followed [42]. Ferric sulphate (6.0g) and ferrous sulphate (4.2g) were dissolved in water (250mL) and stirred at 60°C to give yellowish-orange solution. Under vigorous mechanical stirring, 25% NH4OH (15mL) was added, with which colour of the bulk solution changed to black. Stirring was continued for another 30min. The precipitated nanoparticles were separated magnetically and washed several times with deionized water and ethanol. For encapsulating the Fe3O4 with silica [43], suspended solution of activated Fe3O4 with 0.1M HCl (0.5g) was prepared in a mixture of ethanol (200mL) and water (50mL) under sonication. Then, 25% NH4OH (5mL) was added to the suspension at room temperature followed by the addition of TEOS (1mL). The resultant mixture was kept for stirring at a temperature of 60°C for 6h. The obtained silica coated magnetic nanoparticles (Si–Fe3O4) were separated magnetically, washed with ethanol and dried under vacuum. Finally, in order to functionalize the prepared nanoparticles with amine groups, dispersed solution of Si–Fe3O4 (0.1g) in ethanol (100mL) was made under sonication. 3-Aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) (0.5mL) was then added and resulting mixture was stirred for 6h at 50°C. The developed aminopropylated silica coated magnetic nanoparticles (Am–Si–Fe3O4) were separated and washed several times with ethanol to remove the unreacted silylating agent. 2.3.2 Cu(II)-acetylacetonate complex grafted silica coated magnetite supported nanocatalyst (Cu-Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4) Cu(acac)2 (acac=acetylcetonate) complex was prepared according to the green reported procedure [44]. For the covalent grafting of Cu(acac)2 complex, the dispersed solution of Am–Si–Fe3O4 (4g) and Cu(acac)2 (0.75mmol) was made in chloroform and refluxed for 4h. The resulting copper complex grafted nanoparticles (Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4) were separated, washed with ethanol and dried overnight in a vacuum oven (Scheme 1 ). 2.4 General procedure for the spectrophotometric determination of the reduction of 4-nitrophenol 0.25mL of aqueous o-nitroaniline (o-NA) solution (3.4mmol) was dissolved in 10mL of double distilled water in the quartz cuvette to give a yellow coloured solution. To it, 2.5mL of fresh NaBH4 (1.2M) was added and stirred. Then 10mg of catalyst was added and stirring was continued. Afterwards, a small portion of the reaction mixture was withdrawn and its absorbance recorded by UV–vis spectrophotometer. Reaction monitoring was repeated at regular time intervals until the complete disappearance of the colour was achieved. 2.5 General experimental procedure for the reduction of nitroarenes. 1.07mmol of nitroarenes and 0.05mol of fresh NaBH4 were stirred in 10mL of deionized water, and then 20mg of catalyst was added and stirred for the appropriate amount of time. The progress of the reaction was monitored by GC at regular intervals. After completion, the reaction mixture was cooled and the catalyst was allowed to settle at the side of the vessel using external magnet. Rest of the solution was taken out with dropper and extracted with ethyl acetate (3×10mL). It was further washed with 10% NaHCO3 and water solution and dried over Na2SO4. The structure elucidations of the products were confirmed by GC–MS. The separated catalyst was first washed with double-distilled water and then with acetone to remove any traces of organic material. It was then dried and used as it is for further reactions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization 3.1.1 Shape, morphology and purity of nanoparticles The shape, size and morphological characteristics of the prepared magnetite nanoparticles, before and after surface modifications, were scrutinized using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and Scanning electron microscopy (SEM). A close examination of the TEM image in Fig. 1a reveals that the magnetic nanoparticles are quasi-spherical with the average diameter of 8–12nm. The selected area electron diffraction pattern (SAED) of the magnetic nanoparticles particles is shown as an inset in Fig. 1a. The array of bright diffraction rings as well as white spots indicates that the obtained magnetic nanoparticles produced by the above stated method are highly crystalline in nature. Besides this, the high resolution TEM image (HR-TEM) confirms the magnetite phase purity using 2D lattice fringes in Fig. 1b, the average interfringe distance of obtained nanoparticles is measured to be ∼0.3nm, which corresponds to the (220) lattice plane of the inverse spinel structure of Fe3O4 nanoparticles. The nanoparticles, depicted in Fig. 1c after silica encapsulation step, have a discrete core–shell structure, and their uniform magnetic core is surrounded by 3–5nm thick silica shell. Structure in Fig. 1d reveals the grafting of organic polymer (APTES) onto the surface of silica coated nanoparticles for the functionalization of Si–Fe3O4. The surface and morphology of Fe3O4 and Si–Fe3O4 nanoparticles are also revealed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). An assessment of the SEM images captured in Fig. 1e and f confirms the change in morphology of magnetite nanoparticles after silica encapsulation. The smooth surface of the Fe3O4 transformed to be rough and uneven, due to the formation of a uniform and continuous silica shell over magnetic core. It is important to mention here, that separate silica aggregates are not observed, which indicates that the precipitation of silica nanoparticles has not occurred. 3.1.2 Phase and structural determination The crystalline structures of both before and after the silica covering were characterized by powder X-Ray diffraction (XRD) (Fig. 2 ). The XRD analysis exhibited information about the crystallographic structure, chemical composition, and physical properties of the nanocomposites. As depicted from the diffractogram, the patterns indicate a crystallized structure at 2θ: 30.1°, 35.4°, 43.1°, 53.4°, 57° and 62.6°, which is assigned to the (220), (311), (400), (422), (511) and (440) crystallographic faces of magnetite. No peaks of other crystalline phase were obtained, suggesting the high phase purity of the Fe3O4 nanocore and confirms the TEM results. These results were also compared to the reference Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) X-ray diffraction data in order to deduce the crystal structure. The result confirms the highly crystalline cubic inverse spinel structure with the standard XRD spectrum of Fe3O4 (no. 19-0629). The Debye–Scherrer equation (Dhkl 1/4kl/β cos θ) was used to estimate average crystalline size from the XRD patterns, where D is the size of the axis parallel to the (hkl) plane, k is a constant with a typical value of 0.89 for spherical particles, l is the wavelength of radiation, β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) in radians, and θ is the position of the diffraction peak maximum. Here, the mean crystalline sizes of Fe3O4 nanoparticles were calculated to be 12.9nm by measuring the (311) peak widths of the X-ray diffraction lines [45]. The XRD pattern of Si–Fe3O4 nanoparticles synthesized by the Stöber process, shows a broad diffusion peak at 2θ =15–24° that appeared due to the existence of poorly crystalline silica [46]. Other than this, there is no any substantial variation was observed in the rest of the XRD pattern of Si–Fe3O4, revealing the retention of the original crystallographic structural characteristic of magnetite (Fe3O4) even after the extreme chemical and physical conditions created during the silica coating process. Whereas, broadening of these XRD peaks could be due to the synergistic effect of amorphous silica coating. The elemental mapping of the nanoparticles at different stages (Si–Fe3O4, Am–Si–Fe3O4 and Cu(II)–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4) is exemplified through EDS analysis (Fig. 3 ). Fig. 3(a) proved that the product is composed of only silica (Si) and iron (Fe) in Si–Fe3O4. It also showed that Fe and Si are distributed throughout the structure, without forming the individual aggregates. Whereas, Fig. 3(b) showed the attachment of aminopropyl groups over Si–Fe3O4, by displaying the decline in the Fe content and increase in Si and Nitrogen (N) in Am–Si–Fe3O4. Fig. 3(c) reveals the presence of copper over the Cu(II)–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4 surface framework; it provides the vital qualitative evidence of the metal immobilization on the prepared nanocatalyst. The quantitative assaying of copper content in catalyst was performed using AAS, and sample digestion was carried out in the microwave at 400W for 15min. at constant pressure programme with 5mL aqua regia. Standard reference solutions for copper measurement were made to obtain the calibration curves. 0.155mmolg−1 copper content in catalyst was quantified using a calibration curve in triplicate. The composition and chemical structure of the final nanocatalyst (Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4) and parent nanocomposites (Fe3O4, Si–Fe3O4 and Am–Si–Fe3O4) were characterized by Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). The adsorption peak in Fig. 4(a) at around 580cm−1 is the characteristic absorption of FeO bond, which confirmed the presence of iron oxide in the core and broad band around 3122cm−1 due to OH stretching vibrations of adsorbed water [47]. After stabilizing the Fe3O4 with silica, the FT-IR spectra in Fig. 4(b) shows pronounced change in the 1300–700cm–1 region. The peaks at 953 and 1090cm–1 correspond to the characteristic SiOSi bond, typically attributed to the SiO symmetric stretching and SiOSi asymmetric stretching vibrations, respectively [48]. A significant reduction of the intensity of the FeO stretching and bending vibrations bands are also observed in contrast to naked Fe3O4, which further verify the encapsulation of silica over iron nano core. The characteristic absorption bands are also observed at 3378cm−1 and 1633cm−1 due to stretching and bending vibrations of physically adsorbed water and hydrogen bonded surface silanol groups. After functionalization in the amino modified nanoparticles (Am–Si–Fe3O4) in Fig. 4(c), the band at 2926cm−1 corresponds to the CH2 group of the amino-propyl group (which is absent in former Si–Fe3O4 spectrum) [48]. The spectrum of the Cu(II)–Acac grafted over Am–Si–Fe3O4 in Fig. 4(d), shows a strong band at 1624cm−1 due to the CN bond formation and its stretching vibration [49]. This confirms the covalent grafting of metal-complex (Cu–Acac) onto the surface of Am–Si–Fe3O4 (Supplementary material). 3.1.3 Property characterization To study the magnetic properties of Fe3O4, Si–Fe3O4 and Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4, the hysteresis loops of these particles were registered in the curve shown in Fig. 5 . The graph indicates the field-dependent magnetization curve as a function of applied magnetic field measured at room temperature (293K) with the field sweeping from −20,000 to 20,000Oe using a superconducting quantum interference device with a field of 2T at room temperature using vibrating-sample magnetometer. The inset of all the curves in Fig. 5, showed almost negligible coercivity & remanence effect as both the magnetization and demagnetization curves in all were passing through the origin. This authenticates the superparamagnetism phenomenon in the prepared nanoparticles. As could be seen from Fig. 5, the hysteresis loop of the Fe3O4 showed highest saturation magnetization (M s ) of 54emug−1, which is lower than the saturation magnetization of the Fe3O4 bulk materials (M s =92emug−1). The reason behind the difference is that the extent of magnetization of a magnetic particle in an external field is proportional to its size value of that particle. Therefore, a smaller saturation magnetization value for the magnetite nanoparticles compared to the bulk material is reasonable. While after incorporation of SiO2 in Si–Fe3O4 and metal–ligand complex over functionalized silica in Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4, M s value decreases to 28 and 19emug−1, which can be attributed to the contribution of the dead layer non-magnetic SiO2 shell and metal complex moiety to the total mass of particles [49–51]. It should be also noted that, the black magnetite nanoparticles can be easily oxidized to brownish Fe2O3 nanoparticles when they are exposed directly to air and their property of magnetism decreases significantly. However, even after six months of storage in air exposed environment at room temperature, the colour and the magnetic properties of Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4 remained almost unchanged. This test confirms that coating of SiO2 layer over Fe3O4 shielded the nano-magnetite surface from air contact, which improves the stability and enhances the shelf-life of nano-catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic activity of the catalyst in reduction of nitroarenes To check the catalytic capability of the catalyst, the reduction of o-nitroaniline (o-NA) to their corresponding amine derivatives in the presence of NaBH4 was chosen as a model reaction. To further evaluate the efficiency of the catalyst, different control experiments were performed and the obtained data is shown in Table 1 . As can be seen, the present catalyst (Cu–AcTp@Am–Si–Fe3O4) gives the desired product with maximum conversion and selectivity in the given reaction conditions. Also, the time dependence catalytic activity of Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4 has been monitored by UV–vis spectrophotometer. Fig. 6 shows that after the addition of the small amount of Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4, the absorbance at 412nm successively decreases and nearly disappears in 5min. At the same time, a shift of the peak is observed from 282 to 289nm. These indicate the gradual reduction of o-NA to its amine daughter derivatives. Furthermore, the UV–vis absorption profiles suggest that the reduction of o-NA gives only benzenediamine as the single product, which has also been further confirmed by GC–MS. 3.2.1 Effect of catalyst loading To investigate the effect of catalyst loading on nitroarenes degradation, different amount of catalyst (5, 10, 15, 20 and 25) is tested, the results obtained for quantitative analysis of the nanocatalyst for the o-NA reduction as a function of time is shown in Fig. 7 . As depicted, the addition of sole base does not show any conversion. However, with the addition of catalyst and with increasing concentration of the catalyst, the reduction of o-nitroaniline enhances. This could be mainly due to the availability of a large number of active sites on the surface of the catalyst, which increases with the amount of the catalyst. While after a certain extent, the reactant molecules available are not sufficient for adsorption by the increase in number of catalytic sites. Hence, beyond a certain amount the additional catalyst will not participate in the reaction. Therefore, the catalytic efficiency is almost same for the catalyst concentration of 20 and 25mg. Hence, 20mg has been taken as an optimal catalyst concentration for further experiments. 3.2.2 Effect of various solvent and base To examine the effect of various solvents and base on the catalytic activity of Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4, the effect of various bases (NH2NH2, NaBH4, NH4Cl) have been tested with a series of solvents such as methylene chloride, toluene, H2O, N,N-dimethylformamide and methanol. Among the various conditions checked in Fig. 8 , it has found that present nanocatalyst under aqueous environment showed maximum conversion (100%) and selectivity with NaBH4 as a base. The experimental results reveal that reaction does not proceed in organic solvents, whereas the reduction goes efficiently in water. Interestingly the reaction virtually failed to initiate the reaction, even in methanol. Thus, water has a decisive role in this reaction. After examining the promotional effect of different bases, only strong nucleophile such as NaBH4, due to its diffusive nature and high electron injection capability shows excellent results by transfer of electrons to the substrates via copper nanocatalyst, which helps to overcome the kinetic barrier of the reaction. 3.2.3 Kinetic studies Since the concentration of NaBH4 is higher than that of o-NA, the rate of reduction is independent of the concentration of NaBH4 and the reaction can be considered as a constant during the reaction period, the rate constants for the reduction of o-NA is allowed to evaluate by the pseudo-first-order kinetics. As the absorbance of o-NA is proportional to its concentration in the medium, the ratio of the absorbance at time t(A t ) to that at t =0 (A 0) is proportional to the concentration at time t (C t ) to that of t =0 (C 0) i.e. A t /A 0 α C t /C0. The pseudo first order law can be fitted reasonably well to nearly 99% of the conversion for the reaction. We have also made a comparison of the performance of different ways of attached catalysts. To confirm the difference in the activity, the catalytic rates were measured and analysed for o-NA reduction. The rate constants K were estimated directly from the slope of the straight line obtained by plotting ln C t /C 0 versus time for two types of catalyst as shown in Fig. 9 . For Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4, K app was found to be 1.07s−1, Cu directly attached to support Cu@Am–Si–Fe3O4 gave lower K app values. A comparison of the K app values has been provided in Table 2 . Generally, the efficacy of catalyst depends on the size, site density, stability and metal-support interaction. In this work, the different reduction rate should mainly attribute to the metal–support interaction. Though in this case, the reaction is catalyzed by Cu ions, but the role of ligand is also accountable for the present transformation. Here, Cu–Acetylacetonate complex grafted nanocatalyst (Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4) in contrast to the Cu, which is directly attached to support (Cu@Am–Si–Fe3O4) possess strong σ donation by O and N atoms, which not only acts as a co-catalyst and but also bounds the copper metal ion effectively. 3.2.4 Scope of the catalytic activity on different substrates The scope of the catalytic activity of Cu(II)–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4 in the reduction for different substituted aromatic nitro compounds was examined. All the catalytic conditions of these analogues are same as that of o-NA and the reaction progress of the nitroarenes is monitored by UV–vis spectrometry. The conversion and selectivity were determined by GC–MS analysis of the residual nitrobenzene in the mixture after reaction. As shown in Tables 3a and 3b , our catalyst showed good catalytic activity with excellent yield towards a series of nitroarenes compounds. The reduction was uniform irrespective of the nature of the subsituents on the aromatic ring. The easily reducible functionalities such as Me, OMe, CH3, CN, OH and Br remained totally unaffected. In general, the reductions were very clean, giving the amines with high yields. No intermediate products such as hydroxylamine or hydrazine were found after the reaction was over. 3.3 Comparison of the prepared catalyst with the recent literature precedents The literature review shows that various catalysts have been tested for the degradation of nitroarenes [14–17,30–31,52–54]. Therefore, their catalytic efficiencies have been compared with those obtained by using Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4 catalyst. It is evident from Tables 3a and 3b that the present catalytic system is superior to the recently reported catalysts in terms of easy work up, mild reaction conditions, short reaction time, easy recovery and reusability of the catalyst. Further, it should also be noted that most of the catalysts which have been previously reported for the present reaction were based on precious metals. These catalysts are not only costly, but also scarce in nature. Besides, the work reported with copper based catalysts followed the homogeneous approach [28–31]. These catalysts decomposed immediately after the reaction and could not be recovered. On the contrary to this, Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4 as catalyst is stable, readily available, economical and can be recovered simply by using external magnet and reused for several cycles without any significant loss in its catalytic activity. 3.4 Plausible reaction mechanism In the present transformation, the reaction has not occurred in the absence of catalyst, which indicates that the Lewis acidity of the catalyst plays a significant role. On the other hand, reaction in the presence of Cu(II) acetylacetonate complex immobilized nanocatalyst (Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4) yields the desired product with the highest conversion and selectivity. As depicted in Scheme 2 , in the presence of a surplus amount of NaBH4, NaBH4 ionizes in an aqueous medium with the generation of borohydride ions [51], which adsorb onto the surface of the copper nanocomposites and react to form copper–hydride complex. Nitroarenes also adsorb onto the surface of copper nanocatalyst and both the process are reversible i.e., adsorption and desorption. Once both the substrates are chemisorbed over the catalyst surface, there is hydrogen transfer from the copper hydride complex to nitroarenes. Now, there are two plausible routes for the reduction of the nitro-group to amino group based on the Haber electrochemical model (Scheme 3 ), first is direct route and the other route is condensation method. In the direct route, the aromatic nitro compound is reduced to the nitroso compound and then to hydroxylamine by very fast consecutive steps. Finally, the hydroxylamine is reduced to the amine derivative in the rate determining step. The other route of condensation involves the formation of azoxy compound via condensing nitroso intermediate with hydroxylamine, which in turn follows a series of consecutive steps to the azo, hydrazo to finally amine derivative. Tilve et al. have beautifully demonstrated that the mechanism for copper driven reduction of nitroarenes with both the reduction pathways [30]. GC–MS studies did not show any traces of unreacted nitrosobenzene but phenyl hydroxylamine and azobenzene were present in the reaction mixture, which decreased with time to yield more towards the desired product. This signifies that both the pathways (i.e. direct as well as condensation) follow the reduction process via directly from hydroxyl amine and via azobenzene intermediates. The absence of nitrosobenzene in the reaction mixture signifies that it gets adsorbed very strongly on to the surface of the catalyst and reacts before the reaction begins. Also to further verify the observation azobenzene was also separately reduced, but same amine product formation took place after 5min. 3.5 Hot filtration experiment A hot-filtration test was conducted to verify whether the reduction of o-NA catalyzed by catalyst follows a heterogeneous pathway. First, AAS analysis of the post reaction mixture, after the catalyst separation, was conducted and the results revealed that concentration of Cu(II) ions in the supernatant corresponds to the negligible catalyst leaching. Another reaction was carried out with the procured catalyst from previous cycle. It was found that the concentration of o-NA was 69% in 2min. After the catalyst was separated using external magnet and the filtrate was again poured back into the vessel and the reaction was continued for another 30min. The supernatant was again monitored timely and found that there was almost no further conversion after separation of the catalyst (Fig. 10 ). It corroborated that the copper ions have not been etched out during the course of the reaction which further signifies the stability and heterogeneity of prepared nanocatalyst. To further intensify the fact, the catalyst recovered after this run was subjected to digestion using microwave and metal content analysis using AAS. The result showed that there was barely any change in the metal amount in contrast to the fresh catalyst (0.151mmolg−1), which further confirms that present catalyst (Cu–Acac@Am–Si–Fe3O4) follows heterogeneous pathway. 3.6 Recycling of catalyst Reusability is a key feature for any heterogeneous catalyst, as it provides information about the type of immobilization process and catalytic stability with continuous catalytic runs. For executing the recycling and reusability experiments, the catalyst was fixed magnetically at the side wall of the vessel (complete separation within 30s) and the remaining solution was taken off with a dropper. Then, the vessel was recharged for another reaction. The result of the next run confirmed that the catalyst can be re-used and can be further subjected for progressive reactions with fresh substrates. The experimental results of successive nine reactions demonstrated that the reactivity of the catalyst did not undergo any appreciable change in its activity and only a steady decline in the yield was observed due to the loss of catalyst during the handling and separation. The morphology and stability of the recovered catalyst isolated after 9th run was assessed from the SEM and VSM analysis. Although during the reaction, nanocatalysts were subjected to continuous stirring; it is evident from SEM image (Fig. 11 ) of reused catalyst that nanoparticles remain intact confirming its good mechanical strength. Likewise SEM, VSM analysis also illustrates that the saturation magnetization values of the reused catalyst almost remain unaltered (18.9emug−1) (Supplementary information). 4 Conclusions In summary, we have presented an economically viable and energy efficient catalytic process using copper based nanocatalyst for the selective reduction of nitroarenes in aqueous condition at room temperature. The simple operation, stability and rigidity of catalyst, use of inexpensive and benign magnetic nanoparticles as support, easy recoverability and reusability, less demanding conditions and above all, the yield of amines with high selectivity in short reaction time with zero effluent discharge makes it an environmentally acceptable and greener alternative, when compared to the other reported catalytic system for the reduction of nitroarenes. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, the fabrication of a highly efficient magnetically separable organic–inorganic hybrid nanocatalyst has been reported by covalently immobilizing the copper(II) acetylacetonate complex over amine functionalized silica@magnetite nanoparticles. The prepared nanocatalyst was characterized by electron microscopy techniques (SEM and TEM with EDS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), vibrational sampling magnetometer (VSM), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) techniques. The catalytic performance of the resulting nano-composites was examined for the degradation of various organic nitro-analogues in aqueous medium at room temperature using sodium-borohydride as the source of hydrogen. This nano-catalytic system selectively reduces the nitro group even in presence of other sensitive functional groups. To achieve the best catalytic efficacy, various parameters such as catalyst loading, reaction time, effect of various bases and solvents etc. were optimized. The reaction kinetics for the reduction of o-nitroaniline to benzenediamine was studied by UV–vis spectroscopy, and its apparent rate constant was determined and compared with different copper nanocatalysts. The identification of organic residues and purity of the obtained products was analysed by GC–MS. The acquisition of this nanocatalyst has been demonstrated by employing the catalyst in hot filtration and reusability test, and the results obtained from the tests show negligible metal leaching. The nano-catalytic system can be efficiently recovered using simple magnet and reused for multiple cycles without appreciable loss in its catalytic activity. In addition, the stability of the recycled catalyst has been proved by SEM and VSM techniques. It is noteworthy that the key-features like mild reaction conditions, simple work-up procedure, high turnover frequency (TOF), no use of toxic organic solvents, ease in recovery and reusability of the catalyst makes the present protocol more fascinating from an environmental and economic point of view.
coredata.dc:title: Magnetically separable silica@Fe3O4 core–shell supported nano-structured copper(II) composites as a versatile catalyst for the reduction of nitroarenes in aqueous medium at room temperature
